channel.title: UFO Sightings Of August 2012
channel.description:
Do you believe?... [youtube]http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sFfzGV9g-N0[/youtube]
Or is it all just new military technological concept aircraft but govt has brainwash the masses to believe theres ufo's to keep us from demanding real truth or any commission inquires.
We have so far discovered 9 in our solar system, and 185 orbiting other stars (as of April. 2006).
But the real number is astronomically huge. There are about 400 billion stars in our galaxy alone. If each of them have the same number of planets (on average) as our own sun, then that's about 4 trillion planets in our own galaxy alone. Multiply that by an estimated 125 billion galaxies in the universe ... that's a lot of planets.
As for when they were discovered, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn (and of course, the Earth) are visible to the naked eye and have been known as long as we've looked into the sky. Uranus was formally discovered as a planet in 1781. Neptune was discovered in 1846. Pluto was discovered in 1930. Another body, larger than Pluto, was discovered in 2005. Currently named 2003 UB313, it is not yet officially classified as a planet (but may be reclassified in September of this year).
The first extrasolar planet (a planet orbiting another star) was officially discovered in 1993, lots were found in the late 90's, and so far we have discovered a total of 185.
I think it would be selfish to say there isn't other living organisms.

item.title: UFO Sightings Of August 2012
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:31, topic:458032”][quote author=Carter_ link=topic=560957.msg4095379#msg4095379 date=1346786476]
because i don’t need a child telling me right from wrong thanks.
[/quote]

well, the definition of a planet was defined by the international astronomical union, you seem to be the child telling them right from wrong if anything[/quote]
It is like a lot of people should demand that the Czech Republic and Slovakia would be renamed to Czechoslovakia because that was the name when they were younger.

No, it is the best that Pluto was kicked out of the planet club, or else the definition planet would lose it value.

Read full topic

item.title: UFO Sightings Of August 2012
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Carter_:

Because it was classed as a planet once before and I disagreed with the change, as did members of the Science community. Planets beyond Pluto are obsolete because they have never been classed as a planet.

so, first you wonder what a definition of the planet really is, and then when one is properly defined you still want pluto to be a planet but not other dwarf planets which fall into the same category as pluto, because they’re obsolete? fuck labels man I’m a fucking dinosaur because I say so!

Carter_:

And a dwarf human is still a human.

scientific names of terms often have very little to do with the terminology of the term, and in this case “dwarf human” is still wrong because there’s no such thing as a dwarf human, there are humans with dwarfism, that is, there are humans that are short because of medical complications

dwarf planets are not planets because their orbit of a star is aided by other celestial objects, our moon is not a planet because its orbit of the sun is aided by the earth which orbits the sun unaided

Read full topic

item.title: UFO Sightings Of August 2012
item.dc:creator: @Team_Rocket Team_Rocket
item.description:
@Team_Rocket wrote:

[quote=“Carter_, post:13, topic:458032”][quote author=Niall link=topic=560957.msg4093994#msg4093994 date=1346669624]

The first extrasolar planet (a planet orbiting another star) was officially discovered in 1993, lots were found in the late 90’s, and so far we have discovered a total of 185.

more like 778 planets, as of sept 2nd 2012

I grew up with it being classified as a planet so I still consider it one. What truly classifies a planet anyway, as there are moons around Jupiter larger than Mercury. It’s just political correctness and Pluto should still be classed as a planet in my opinion.

if you want to know why pluto isn’t considered a planet but a dwarf planet go look up the iau debate on it you dope, quaoar, sedna, eris all have comparable size and orbits to that of pluto (which is shared with much of the orbits of objects in the kuiper belt), should they be considered planets too?
[/quote]

Yes, you “dope”.[/quote]

Niall is correct…

Read full topic
